posts.post_content:
You can counter [Surgical Extraction](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Surgical Extraction) with another [Surgical Extraction](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Surgical Extraction). Your opponent casts [Surgical Extraction](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Surgical Extraction) targeting something you want to keep in your deck, let's say your [Mental Misstep](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mental Misstep), you cast [Surgical Extraction](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Surgical Extraction) in response to theirs targeting your own Mental Misstep, choose to only exile the one that your opponent is targeting and fail to find the rest of them. When your opponent's spell goes to resolve it gets countered since its only target is now an illegal target, saves you from revealing your hand and your entire library. I can see this being a 4 of for every sideboard for a very long time.
  
   
Bye-Bye [Bloodghast](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Bloodghast), Bye-Bye [Valakut, the Molten Pinnacle](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Valakut, the Molten Pinnacle), and Bye-Bye [Wurmcoil Engine](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Wurmcoil Engine). For added laughs, mill/discard your opponent's [Ulamog, the Infinite Gyre](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Ulamog, the Infinite Gyre) and Extract it in response to t... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

When your opponent's spell goes to resolve it gets countered since its only target is now an illegal target, saves you from revealing your hand and your entire library. I can see this being a 4 of for every sideboard for a very long time.

posts.post_content:
Mean people in Vintage will have played all four of theirs by turn three, then drop a [Yawgmoth's Will](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Yawgmoth's Will) and do it again.   
  
One other thing to keep in mind with this card: 75-95% of competitive decks use non-basic lands. This thing can KILL those kinds of decks.  
  
EDIT: "Mean people in Vintage"--are there any other kinds of people who play Vintage? ;-)

posts.post_content: I know some people are talking about Extirpate, but that's not Type 2 standard now is it? Being able to harm a deck in such was is extremely good in standard, especially when you can do so with such speed. \*\*\*, I dropped this on a dude 5 times in one match (3 of those was in 1 round) and I essentially wrecked his deck. I also use Haunting Echoes for later game so I can wreck their deck even further, just to take away all hopes of winning (people usually scoop when that hits).

posts.post_content:
You can counter this. In fact, if not countering it means losing all your Mana Leaks or Jaces (or Mental Missteps), you might have to. But then you just spent 1 or 2 mana countering a spell which cost its controller 0 mana, giving them time to squeeze out an actual threat.  
  
Control spells that don't cost mana are extremely powerful. Mental Misstep is even more amazing (and is a direct foil to this), but this is still amazing.

Control spells that don't cost mana are extremely powerful. Mental Misstep is even more amazing (and is a direct foil to this), but this is still amazing.

posts.post_content:
I think this has a one-up on extirpate in some ways. This combo's with itself and is very unpredictable (if they need that card you target and FoW it, you can surgical again, or you may even just tear out the FoWs from the deck!) You can tap out whenever you want, draw counters from the enemy on something important and let's say they counter something you cared about, at least you can eliminate that entire playset of counterspell from their deck for 2 life.   
  
Yes, most real decks can survive without certain specific cards but some can't. Ichorid for example needs [ichorid](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=ichorid), [bridge from below](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=bridge from below), and usually some other minor players and becomes much worse. If they rely on just a [golgari grave-troll](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=golgari grave-troll) for their dredging theirs a good chance you can screw the deck in one shot on the opponent's turn 1.   
  
Extirpate is irreplaceable, but this is a good second best and definitely has it's place in almost any main-deck IMO. I love being a... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

Posted By: blurrymadness (6/28/2011 4:41:29 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Not great in every deck. Not good *against* every deck.  
  
And still exactly what a few decks need to beat a few other decks (great insurance in UWC/UBC vs. [Tempered Steel](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Tempered Steel), for instance). And likely to increase in value as the Innistrad block gives us more and more encouragement to put our own cards into the graveyard.  
  
It looks like most comments here are either overvaluing it as the best card to hit standard since the Urza's block or undervaluing it as nothing but jank. Honestly, it's neither; just another situational card that, when said situation arises, has just as much or more reason to be played than any other card.  
  
  
Also, confession time: I'm the reason Tempted\_Johnny hates control. :p (Although I don't run caw so I don't know what he's hoping to exile.)
posts.html:
Not great in every deck. Not good against every deck.

And still exactly what a few decks need to beat a few other decks (great insurance in UWC/UBC vs. Tempered Steel, for instance). And likely to increase in value as the Innistrad block gives us more and more encouragement to put our own cards into the graveyard.

It looks like most comments here are either overvaluing it as the best card to hit standard since the Urza's block or undervaluing it as nothing but jank. Honestly, it's neither; just another situational card that, when said situation arises, has just as much or more reason to be played than any other card.


Also, confession time: I'm the reason Tempted_Johnny hates control. :p (Although I don't run caw so I don't know what he's hoping to exile.)
